analytic.title: Millimeter-Wave Channel Estimation Based on Two-Dimensional Beamspace MUSIC Method

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: Due to the spatial sparsity caused by the severe propagation loss, the millimeter-wave (mm-wave) channel estimation can be performed by estimating the directions and gains of the paths that have significant power. In this paper, we apply the beamspace two-dimensional multiple signal classification (MUSIC) method to estimate the path directions (the angles of departure and arrival) and use the least-squares method to estimate the path gains. Different from its element-space counterpart, the beamspace MUSIC method may exhibit spectrum ambiguity caused by the beamformers. In this paper, we therefore analyze the sufficient conditions on the beamformers under which the MUSIC spectrum has no ambiguity which also leads to the maximum number of resolvable path directions. Moreover, based on the uniform linear array with half-wavelength spacing, we show that the discrete Fourier transform (DFT) beamformers, which are naturally analog and often employed in the mmwave communication systems with hybrid precoding structure, can avoid the spectrum ambiguity and maximize the number of resolvable path directions. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed two-dimensional beamspace MUSIC mm-wave channel estimator significantly outperforms existing estimators that are based on beam training and sparse recovery; and in the meantime, it requires much less training slots than these existing methods.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: Millimeter wave (mm-wave) communication is a potential candidate technology for next-generation wireless communication systems [1][2][3][4]. One key characteristic of the mm-wave systems is the severer propagation loss compared with the micro wave systems [4][5][6]. For example, the propagation characteristics of the E-band signals are summarized in [5]. Thus the traditional multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) channel models based on rich scattering fail to characterize the spatial sparsity of the mm-wave channel, whose impulse response is dominated by only a small number of scattering paths. Instead the mm-wave channel can be modeled in the parametric form, in terms of the path angles of departure/arrival (AoD/AoA) and the corresponding path gains. As a result, the mmwave channel estimation problem becomes estimating the path directions (angle pairs) and gains rather than estimating the MIMO channel matrix [7][8][9].

The mm-wave channel estimation is often combined with beamforming, which is used to combat the severe path loss. Since the mm-wave signals are highly directional and consist of a few significant components, a straightforward and lowcomplexity mm-wave channel estimation method is to search in the angular space by adjusting the steering directions of the beamformer [7,[10][11][12][13]. However, the exhaustive search may be hampered by the high training overhead in practice. Efficient beam training strategies based on compressed sensing (CS) [14] are developed in [7,[11][12][13] where the estimation procedures are divided into multiple stages. At the initial stage, the angular space is coarsely searched with wide beams. In the subsequent stages, the searching beams become narrower and narrower. Finally, the estimated AoDs/AoAs achieve the desired resolution at the last stage.

Different from beam training methods, [8] utilized the orthogonal matching pursuit algorithm to solve the mm-wave channel estimation problem and also gave some insight into the hybrid digital/analog precoding structure that has been widely adopted in the mm-wave communications systems [7,[15][16][17]. Moreover, the massive MIMO channel estimation problem is also treated using the CS-based methods in [18,19]. These CS-based methods regard the sparse multipath channel estimation as a sparse recovery problem. The virtual angular representation [18,20] or angle grids [8] are used to describe the path directions. For each angle grid that represents a pair of TX/RX directions, there is a gain coefficient. Because of the spatial sparsity of the mm-wave channel, most of the gain coefficients should be zero, which means there is no path coming from/to those directions. The sparse recovery method aims to recover the nonzero gain coefficients, which naturally provides the estimates of the path directions, and at the same time reduces the training overhead as much as possible.

The channel estimation schemes mentioned above can be used to estimate the full channel state information (CSI). In [21], the Arnoldi iteration technique is applied to estimate the partial CSI of the mm-wave channel, i.e., the right and the left singular vectors are estimated at the transmitter and the receiver respectively. Similarly, [22] and [23] also develop iterative approaches to estimate the partial CSI of the mm-wave channel. In particular, [22] aims to find the steering vector corresponding to the strongest path. The method developed in [24], which exploits the knowledge of the channel covariance matrix, can be used to solve the mm-wave channel estimation Fig. 1: A mm-wave communication system employing hybrid analog/digital beamforming. problem too.

Different from the prior works mentioned above, we solve the mm-wave channel estimation problem based on the spatial spectrum estimation (SSE) method [25]. Particularly, we use the two-dimensional beamspace multiple signal classification (MUSIC) approach and the least-squares method to estimate the path directions and path gains respectively. MUSIC is a classic method for estimating the angle-of-arrivals (AoAs) and has been employed in [26] for mm-wave communication systems. It can be easily extended to estimate the AoDs and AoAs jointly [27,28]. In particular, [28] considers the fast implementation of the two-dimensional MUSIC. However, the one-and two-dimensional MUSIC algorithms in [26][27][28] are all performed in the element-space, which are impractical to be implemented with a small number of RF chains. For mm-wave communications employing hybrid beamforming, the receiving signals are first mixed by the beamformer and then sent to the RF chains. Thus for the channel estimation problem, it is the beamspace MUSIC that really works. The main contributions of this paper are summarized as follows:

1) We propose a new mm-wave channel training scheme inspired by the measurement results in [6], which show that at mm-wave band the clusters' central angles belong to large-scale fading while the path gains belong to small-scale fading. It means that we should be able to observe the path directions in a time span during which the path gains may have fluctuated significantly. This fluctuation mitigates the deep fading effect and thus helps to increase the estimation accuracy of the path directions.

Besides the beamspace MUSIC, the proposed mm-wave channel estimation framework also accommodates other SSE methods like the beamspace ESPRIT [29] and the maximum likelihood approach [30]. 2) For the mm-wave channel estimator based on the twodimensional beamspace MUSIC, the spectrum ambiguity exists and the identifiability is theoretically solved. For the one-dimensional beamspace MUSIC, the spectrum ambiguity caused by inappropriate beamformers has been analyzed in [31]. To avoid the ambiguity in the twodimensional beamspace MUSIC spectrum, in this paper we provide the sufficient conditions on the beamformers, which also maximize the number of resolvable path directions. Moreover, based on the uniform linear array with half-wavelength spacing, we show that the discrete Fourier transform (DFT) beamformers, which are often used in the hybrid beamforming structure of mm-wave communication systems, satisfy those conditions and thus can be utilized in the proposed channel estimator. The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. Section II presents the system model and introduces some existing mm-wave channel estimation schemes. In Section III, we introduce the two-dimensional beamspace MUSIC method and give sufficient conditions on the beamformers under which there is no ambiguity in estimating the path angles. Simulation results are presented in Section IV. Section V concludes the paper.

div.head: II. SYSTEM DESCRIPTIONS A. System and Channel Model
div.p: Consider a mm-wave communication system shown in Fig. 1. The transmitter and receiver are equipped with N t and N r antennas respectively. The hybrid analog/digital beamforming is adopted, which is a promising scheme that has been widely used to reduce the hardware cost in mm-wave communication systems [7,15]. Within the hybrid structure, the antenna array at the transmitter is connected to the analog beamformer F ∈ C Nt×Mt implemented by phase shifters, and the analog beamformer is connected to M t (≤ N t ) RF chains. The same hybrid structure is used at the receiver, where the analog beamformer W ∈ C Nr×Mr is equipped with M r (≤ N r ) RF chains. The digital processors perform channel estimation and digital precoding. In this paper, we focus only on the mm-wave channel estimation problem.

Because of the sparse scattering, the ray-tracing representation is often used to model the mm-wave channel [6,7]. Assuming that there are K clusters and each one contributes to a resolvable path, the channel model can be written as [7]

In (1), we have assumed that the variation of the channel is only caused by the path gains {α k (q)} K k=1 , while the path angles remain unchanged. This time-varying assumption is based on the mm-wave channel measurements in [6], which show that the clusters' central angles belong to large-scale fading while the path gains belong to small-scale fading. div.head: B. Existing MM-Wave Channel Estimation Methods
div.p: Before we discuss our proposed mm-wave channel estimation scheme, we briefly summarize the methods developed in [7,8,18], which all exploit the angular-domain sparsity. To express such a sparsity, first the angular domain is divided into angle grids. Next we use { φi } Gt i=1 and { θi } Gr i=1 to denote the AoD and AoA grids respectively.

In [18], the angle grids are uniformly separated with G t = N t and G r = N r in the so called virtual representation. In [7,8], the size of the angle grids can be set according to the desired angular resolution. Based on these predefined angle grids, directions of all possible paths are approximated by {( φi , θj ), i = 1, . . . , G t , j = 1, . . . , G r }. Finally channel estimation is formulated as the problem to estimate the path gains associated with all those G t G r directions. Because of the spatial sparsity in the mm-wave channel, it is expected that the propagation paths are along a small number of directions, or in other words, most of the estimated path gains are zero. Following this manner, compressed-sensing-based algorithms have been developed in [18] and [8] to reconstruct the path gains, while a multistage training strategy is presented in [7] to first locate path directions and then estimate path gains.

It should be noticed that the channel estimation schemes in [7,8,18] do not exploit the large-scale fading property of the path directions, which remain unchanged for the entire frame, and their estimation accuracies of the path directions are highly affected by the instantaneous path gains. Since the same algorithms are implemented repeatedly for each fading block, this may lead to heavy computational overhead, especially considering that the methods in [8] and [18] are both iterative procedures. On the other hand, for the proposed channel estimation scheme, the main computation cost resides in the direction finding step, which is performed only once in each frame.

Moreover, the number of training time slots used in one block is different among the above mentioned channel esti-mators. Specifically, N tr training slots are used in [18], while N Beam t and N Beam r training beam patterns are used at the the transmitter and receiver respectively in [8], corresponding to N Beam t N Beam r Mr training slots. For the estimator in [7], the number of training slots is mainly determined by the desired grid resolution, i.e., it requires
div.formula: k 0 K 2 k0K Mr log k0 G K training slots (G t = G r = G), where k 0 ≥ 2 is a predefined integer.

div.head: III. BEAMSPACE MM-WAVE CHANNEL ESTIMATION
div.p: We apply the two-dimensional beamspace MUSIC algorithm to estimate the path directions, and based on the estimated angles we then use the LS method to estimate the path gains.

According to (5), the received signal expression, i.e., the input to the channel estimation algorithm, contains the analog beamformers W and F. Thus the beamforming matrices have direct impact on the channel estimation performance. In this paper, we only consider the paths whose directions are located in the beamforming sectors Ω φ and Ω θ (i.e., φ k ∈ Ω φ and θ k ∈ Ω θ , k = 1, . . . , K), and ignore the paths in the attenuated sectors.

As we can see from (1), the mm-wave channel can be parameterized by the large time-scale (path direction) and small time-scale (path gain) components. For the channel estimation algorithm developed in this paper, these components are estimated separately. In particular, as shown in Fig. 2, the path directions are assumed to be fixed during a frame, consisting of N fading blocks. The buffered N blocks of received signals are first utilized to estimate the path directions {(φ k , θ k )} K k=1 using the two-dimensional beamspace q q N N Fig. 2: The frame structure for the proposed mm-wave channel estimator.

As will be explained in the subsection III-D, inappropriate beamformers may induce spectrum ambiguity such that the path angles cannot be uniquely identified. The estimated path directions then form the basis of estimating path gains in each block. Specifically, using the estimate of path directions, we can estimate the path gains {α k (q)} K k=1 using the least-squares method and then get the estimate of the entire channel matrix H(q), q = 1, . . . , N . According to the discussion above, we need N blocks' pilots to estimate N channels , and we can see from (3) and ( 5) that we need M t training slots in one block.

div.head: D. Analysis of the 2D Beamspace MUSIC Spectrum Ambiguity
div.p: As we can see from the discussion above, the true path directions {(φ k , θ k )} K k=1 contribute to K poles of P (φ, θ), i.e., b H (φ k , θ k )U n = 0 for k = 1, . . . , K. If in addition, it has another pseudo pole (φ K+1 , θ K+1 ) such that b H (φ K+1 , θ K+1 )U n = 0, then we say the two-dimensional beamspace MUSIC method exhibits ambiguity since the true path angles cannot be uniquely identified by searching the poles of P (φ, θ). Such a pseudo pole can only arise in the situation where b(φ K+1 , θ K+1 ) lies in the column space of B, i.e., the vectors {b(φ k , θ k )} K+1 k=1 are linearly dependent. Specific examples of beamforming matrices that cause such an ambiguity in one-dimensional beamspace MUSIC can be found in [31]. In Section IV, an example is provided to show the spectrum ambiguity caused by the beamformers in the twodimensional case.
Based on the above discussions, we have the following proposition that gives the sufficient condition for avoiding the spectrum ambiguity in the two-dimensional beamspace MUSIC.

Remark: To avoid the MUSIC spectrum ambiguity, Theorem 1 provides us with a sufficient condition on the beamformers F and W in (5) so that the two-dimensional beamspace MUSIC method can uniquely identify the path angles. It can be seen as an extension of [31], where the spectrum ambiguity of the one-dimensional MUSIC has been analyzed. The first condition guarantees no zero vector in the direction matrix, otherwise the full column rank condition in Proposition 1 will be violated. The second condition enables us to perform the rank analysis about F and W separately, rather than analyzing the direction matrix directly. This theorem also shows that to perform direction finding, the number of RF chains can be smaller than the number of paths, i.e., we can uniquely identify K path directions even with max{M t , M r } < K. In particular, if we have M t = N t , M r = N r , and set F = I Nt , W = I Nr , then (15) turns into the element-space MUSIC spectrum.

div.head: IV. SIMULATION RESULTS
div.p: In this section, we present simulation results to illustrate the performance of the proposed channel estimator. The uniform linear arrays at the transmitter and receiver are equipped with N t = 32 and N r = 16 antenna elements respectively. There are M t = 8 RF chains at the transmitter and M r = 4 RF chains at the receiver. The DFT beamformers defined in (23) are used in the simulations. For the mm-wave channel, we assume that in the considered beamforming sector Ω φ = [-0.2188, 0.2188] and Ω θ = [-0.1875, 0.1875], all K paths have equal power, i.e., σ 2 k = 1, k = 1, . . . , K [7]. It should be noticed that the equal power assumption enables us to focus on investigating the spectrum ambiguity caused by the beamformers in the two-dimensional beamspace MUSIC method. At the band, the indoor measurements in [36] and the outdoor measurements in [2] show that the number of significant resolvable paths most likely ranges from 1 to 4, including the LoS path and the NLoS ones. The path directions {(φ k , θ k )} K are randomly generated with uniform distribution in [-1, 1]. The signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) is defined as E Ntσ 2 . For the channel estimation performance, we compare the proposed 2-D BMUSIC method with the beam training scheme in [7], the Dantzig selector (DS) -based estimator in [18] 6 , and the orthogonal matching pursuit (OMP) -based estimator in [8]. All results are averaged over 100 frames with N = 40, and in all channel realizations, the path directions {(φ k , θ k )} K k=1 are kept fixed so the variation is only caused by the path gains {α k (q)} K k=1 . In each block, the proposed 2-D BMUSIC method, the DS-based estimator, and the OMP-based estimator (N Beam t = 32, N Beam r = 16) use 8, 100, 128 training slots respectively. For the beam training scheme (k 0 = 2), the required number of training slots is 20 in the case K = 1 (G = 1024) and 288 in the case K = 3 (G = 768). Hence the training overhead of the proposed method is much smaller than that of the other methods to be compared. The grid resolution for AoD and AoA are denoted as ∆φ and ∆θ respectively.

div.head: V. CONCLUSIONS
div.p: We have proposed a new high-resolution mm-wave channel estimation method by exploiting the fact that the path angles vary much more slowly than the path gains. A number of blocks of received signals are used to first estimate the path angles by searching the poles of the two-dimensional beamspace directional spectrum. We provide sufficient conditions based on which the beamformers can be designed to maximize the number of resolvable path directions. We further show that the popular DFT beamformers satisfy these conditions. Unlike the channel estimators based on the sparsity of angle grids, the proposed method benefits from the high-resolution of angle separation of the MUSIC method. Once the angles are estimated, the fading gains in each block within the frame can then be estimated using the least-squares method. Simulation results have demonstrated that with similar angle resolutions, the proposed two-dimensional beamspace MUSIC channel estimator achieves significantly higher estimation accuracy compared with existing methods, with much lower training slots. In this paper, we have focused on the 2-D channel models. For future work, we can extend the proposed method and the analysis to the 3-D case. Moreover, it would be interesting to extend the proposed scheme to MIMO-OFDM systems to solve the wideband mm-wave channel estimation problem.
